reviewText:
Have you ever imagined a cross between Quake and Pokémon? I bet not. And you  probably also never heard of ZanZarah, an obscure German game about a teenage girl visiting a land of fairies. What these things have in common? Well, everything.

In ZanZarah you play as Amy, who goes from London to a magical land of fairies, elves and wonder. This enchanted world is threatened by an ancient evil, your arrival was foretold by a prophecy and all that. Your quest here is to explore the land, help the locals and raise a strong party of fairies to save the world. To recruit new magical creatures, you must first weaken one in combat and then capture it with a special ball. Sounds very familiar, no?

And it doesn’t stop there. ZanZarah offers over 70 magical creatures – including animals, dragons and demons – spread into 12 types: Fire, Water, Nature, Air, Stone, Ice, Chaos, Energy, Psi, Metal, Dark and Light.

Their attacks have the classic effective/noneffective relationships, and in true Pokémon fashion you also get to choose your initial fairy between three types. They even evolve after reaching a certain level.

But here’s the big twist: unlike Pokémon, you won’t battle in turn-based combat, but rather in FPS arenas with elaborate layouts, firing magic blasts at enemies while strafing, dodging and flying!

There are no guns, but each fairy can equip up to four different spells – two offensive and two passive. The game features 120 spells with a wide range of effects, damage, fire rate and mana pool. Spells must be charged before firing – some allow for quick bursts, others are very slow – but charge too much and it will backfire. All of this keeps battles interesting, as you’ll have to figure out the best loadout to use depending on the arena layout or the enemy type you face.

To crown everything, the soundtrack is excellent. Composed by King Einstein, the battle music is exciting, the exploration music is charming and the main theme is a beautiful melody sang by Karina Gretere.

The only real downside - and this will be a deal breaker for some - is that even this new 2015 Steam re-release doesn't run well on modern computers. You'll occasionally get some visual glithces and graphic artifacts, but the worst part is that the game drops to like 5fps when you open a menu, no matter how powerful your PC is.

If you can deal with this, give ZanZarah a try. If not, don't even bother.
voteText: 126 of 133 people (95%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Don't get me wrong, great game. I have fond memories of playing this back when it originally came out, and as you can see from the other reviews, its basically fairy themed third person pokemon with first person 'creature' fights.

I played this out back in the day, and would love to play it out again.

I cannot, however, recommend this game.

Why you ask? Because it ran better on my 1998 Compaq Presario, than my current 8 grand worth of hardware. And I doubt it will ever be fixed, owing to the company that made it going out of business in the mid 2000's, and recently being bought out (in name only) by Nordic Games.

What does this mean for us gamers? Simply that they can release old content (and earn a bit of dough off us sappy sentimental folks) without ever having to commit to fixing the obvious flaws that causes the game to slow to painfully slow fps any time any box of dialog or menu opens over the main screen.

I'm sure a small investment would fix this, and I eagerly await it happening, however I must also resign myself to the fact that it probably won't.

If you want to purchase this out of sentimentality, go right ahead. Otherwise, leave it alone until it's fixed, and don't tarnish your opinion of what is actually quite a great game.

reviewText:
Old school, comparativly to many other game on the market, and it shows, but was also one of the first games I bought after buying my first computer, so it holds sentimental value to me. I was so sad when my computer died, and my new one wouldn't play the CD-ROM (which I still have).

But that's not why you're reading this.

You play as Amy (or whatever you name her). From what the origional player book implies, she's the a-typical loner heroine. She gets runed away to a mystical land where she must cure the faeries that have been poluted. How do you accomplish this, by capturing the feries with orbs after battling them and recruiting them.

Each faery type had their natural weaknesses, nature/grass are weak to fire, who's weak to water, who's weak to nature.  Some mature faster, while other are better attacker, defenders, or support. Water isn't always powerful, but have heals. Nature can poison and run around while regenerating their health. Stone are tough, but rather slow overall, while fire focuses a lot on offence.

As the faery level, they gain skill slots of attack, defence, or support/passive. They are mostly tuned to a single element, but some morph to be able to hold 2, or any, element type.

The faery in the world with you will be the first in battle, and usually offer some benefit in the world around them, like onlock element locks around the maps, or reveal hidden items.

You buy orbs to capture faery in level ranges. You can also buy/sell skills you don't need.

As you gather more faery, you can return home to see them flying around your flat.

The biggest buggy part is the menus. They tend to be jumpy, while the actual gameplay will be a lot smoother. If it could support FULL HD someday, that would be great.

The story is cute, the puzzles aren't too hard, and for me, is a nice relacing game to play.

As a personal suggestion will be re-adjusting the controls to ASDW from their ARROW presets. For me, it makes travel better, and also makes changing faery in battle quicker.

reviewText:
One of the best game ever made

Ask yourself these questions: Do you like fantasy lore, RPG's, FPS, Pokemon, beautiful visuals, great soundtrack, a captivating story and more all that in a beautiful, large and very diverse semi-open world? If any of these are a YES, then go and buy Zanzarah. You will not regret it.
I've been playing this game on and off since it came out (I just recently got it on Steam but I have a lot of hours with my CD). It is in my top 10 games ever, and I've played a lot of games.

Plot: You play as Amy, a eighteen year old girl from London, UK. At the start of the game your house is visited by a swamp goblin Rafi, and he places a magical rune in your attic. Investigating the rune you are transported to the world of Zanzarah — a different realm. A realm of magic and faeries, strange creatures and odd landscapes. But you are transported there for a reason — you are the Chosen One, from the old legends which speak of a human girl to save the world of Zanzarah from an threat and unite Zanzarah with the human world. The story later further reveals that Zanzarah, Earth and the realm of Faeries was the same world and humans, faeries, dwarves, elves, goblins lived in peace. But humans became corrupted and the human world had to be cut off from the magical realms.

Gameplay: The gameplay consists of two main areas, the first is the RPG in which you play as Amy and navigate through the world talking to NPC's and solving platform elements. Amy mostly serves as a faery bag to be honest. The second is the FPS where you take part in faerie battles.
Playing as Amy you can talk to NPC's, collect items, pixies, and most importantly explore the world and capture faeries. Amy can also partake in a
few minigames and puzzles hidden around the world. Capturing faeries is the most important aspect. There are 77 different faeries, divided into twelve elements, each having advantages and weaknesses against eachother. You can only have five faeries in your deck, however you can go back to your house in London anytime in oder to change them. Faeries are usually caught at a low level, and then you have to train them against faeries of their own level in the wilderness (the world is divided into element and level areas) or at several trainers which costs money. Most faeries can evolve upon reaching a certain level into their other, which means they get new stats, look and spell possibilites. The maximum level for faeries is 60, and leveling and catching all faeries will take time and effort. Each faery can have four spells, two offensive and two defensive. Your faery can also gain a joker spell slot which means you can put a spell of a different or any element for it to use. I shall be making a Guide covering most of the game mechanics and good builds and decks.

Combat: The combat only exists inside the Faery battles, and takes form of a FPS in a arena where you can move, fly around and hide. You have two sets of spells, and each has one offensive and one defensive. You can swap these around when not in a battle, and theres a bunch of different spells each changing the way you battle. Mana is limted, and spells can be charged for more damage (which should be done almost always). You can also swap between the five faeries in your deck at anytime, because some faery types do more damage against others. There is a certain tactical feel to it if you look at it at a certain angle, especially for some very difficult battles. The combat is very fun!

Graphics: The graphics are outdated, but still beautiful. The game runs on DirectX 8.1, so it can be a problem streaming using OBS (personal experience). There are no HD resolutions, and it would be nice from Daedalic to update the DirectX and add more resolution options, as well as a windowed option. Apart from the technical stuff, the game still looks very pretty, the world is diverse, and tastefully made. The menus work and look very good.

Sound: The music is fantastic, especially the main theme sung by Kariina Gretere, similar to Enya. The other sound effects are fitting and of great studio quality, however some sounds can very, very, rarely sound too loud. Note that I've played this game for 13 years and I've basically saw and heard everything it could do so the chances for that happening is 1/10000000 for you :)

Multiplayer: The game has some form of TCP/IP LAN multiplayer where you can use your gamesave deck and fight with your friends. You can use third-party programs like Game Ranger or Hamachi to play with your friends. Remember, this is a game from 2002 so don't expect any servers.

Summary: Zanzarah: The Hidden Portal is a fantastic game that you are sure to love and play for a long time. It might be hard at start to get used to all the faery stuff, but the learning curve isn't very steep. The game has some very difficult sections, which require careful deck planning and leveling of faeries. The story can be speed-run in some fifteenish hours, mostly because you need to level up faeries in order to defeat certain enemies blocking passage or to progress the story. However it will surely take you double that much hours to finish the game with a normal tempo, and this just means finishing the main storyline without getting all the faeries or leveling them up, or even trying to collect  everything. To do that it will take at least 100 hours of gameplay if you are fast.
The only real negative sides of the game is the use of DirectX 8.1 if you're streaming, the resolution, and the biggest break is that after you finish the game, there is no save just a cutscene and then the game reloads to the last checkpoint. You can still go back and do whatever you want, just there isn't anything after the ending".

But even with that taken in consideration
date: this is a gem not to be missed
recommended: and is worth more then its price
hoursPlayed: even when it's not on sale.\n\n*        Score                Graphics        7                Sound        9                Story        10                Gameplay        9                Combat        8"

reviewText: A classic 10/10 game, but unplayable on modern hardware. Daedalic released an untouched 13 yo binary hoping it'd work. It does not. Avoid this release until modders sort out the problems, because frankly Daedalic has absolutely no clue how to fix the game. And I'm pretty sure we can forget about a proper Steam integration.

reviewText:
Do you like Pokemon, and first person shooters? Well I bet you didn't know there was a game for you!

First off, let me say this is a very biassed review because I owned this game years ago and used to absolutely LOVE it. True the controls aren't the best but there's a lot of love in this game and its really quite charming. I've only played it a little so far but it seems to be a very stable and faithful port that works fine on newer versions of windows.

There's a very large variety of fairies to collect each with their own elements and attributes and each element has its own strengths and weaknesses, which is why its so easy to compare it to pokemon. But when you enter fights with wild fairies and other fairy trainers it transforms into a somewhat awkward but very playable quake style battle.

All in all its definitely worth getting at this price, especially if you used to love it as much as I did.

reviewText:
**Warning: Some people have experienced severe performance issues with the game if they are running Windows 10 or have an Nvidia video card. There are likely ways to make it work, but expecting this old game to be playable right out of the box if you have either of those would be a mistake.

I played this game years ago, not long after it first came out, and it's easily one of the best sleepers out there. For those curious, it's basically like Pokemon, but instead of going into a turn-based battle when you fight, you go into a first-person, Quake Battle Arena-style deathmatch where you control your creature. It really is an amazing game, and easily one of my all-time favorites.

Pros:
Surprisingly-evoking thematics.
Next-level Pokemon-style game.
Plenty of creatures to choose from.
Complex elemental matchups.
Cool creature evolutions.
The type of game we've wanted since the 90s.
Skill-reliant gameplay.

Cons:
A lack of diverse attack dynamics—no arcing shots, mines, scattershots, etc. Could be easily fixed by a good modding community.
Game IS from 2002, so the graphics are somewhat dated.
Some of the translations for certain attacks are inaccurate/confusing.
Many of the creatures are fairies, which might be challenging to some people's masculinity.
Game is amazing, but a Zanzarah 2 is unlikely due to the length of time that's passed since the games release.

Overall:
BUY THIS GAME. SHARE IT WITH YOUR FRIENDS. IT'S AMAZING.
voteText: 12 of 13 people (92%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
ZanZarah is a rare little gem which can best be described as a fantasy adventure fused witn Pokemon and FPS elements. Core of the game is catching, training and evolving Fairies and having them duel with enemy fairies in a quick FPS arena. Fairies can be captured as well to increase your pool.

The graphics are capped at a resolution of 1024x768 but have aged pretty well in my opinion.

I'd say it's well worth the price - can't do wrong at well under 10$.


However, you should note a few things:

-The game is pretty old and was written for Windows XP or even 98/ME. It can have issues on more modern systems (not having any here on Win 8.1 x64, even without compatibility mode, but other ppl have reported massive issues)

-game doesn't like ALT-TAB, resultinmg in a crash - better not use it while playing

-mouse movement is pretty chunky in the configuration menu, so far this is the only menu where it's happening

-if you have any issues, don't count on any patches coming, since the original publisher went bankrupt shortly after release of the game in 2002, an addon, which was already in production was scrapped


If the game works however, you will be able to play a rare gem, especially if you like Pokemon-style games.

reviewText:
One of my favorite games as a child.

It is comparable with the first Pokemon games in complexity, but the story is far better and you get to fight your battles as FPS in a lot of different arenas.

The game has a multilayer, but I don't know if it is still working -  there you can fight with your trained fairies against others.

One of the most interesting parts of the game is, that there are many strategies to win a fight. For one there are different types that are effective/ineffective against one another. On the other hand you can equip your fairies with different attacks. And different fairies have also different stats (HP, MP, Speed ...).
Depending on your strategy you can beat a FIRE-Fairy with an (ineffective) NATUR-Fairy, because you are fast enough to avoid their attacks while using slow but steadily killing poison attacks :)

Anyway, the game is more than worth its price.

Have fun.

reviewText:
Zanzarah is a very sweet action-rpg set in a fairy tale world.
The heroine is chosen to save the fantasy world of Zanzarah because she's the only one left that believes in this world enough to actually get there.
The game is about exploring, interacting with the locals (elves, goblins, dwarves) and solving their problems, pretty much like all action-rpgs.

What is different about this game is the fairy combat system.
Combat is carried out by your fairies against other fairies. The encounters are semi-random. By avoiding getting close to trees and large rocks you can avoid many of the random encounters.
Once you trigger an encounter, your fairy will be dragged inside the tree or rock where the enemy" fairy was hiding and the combat takes place in that arena.
The combat is in real time and you have to target the enemy fairy with your spells
date:
you can change fairies from your deck during combat and change their spell sets.
Once the enemy fairy is weakened enough you can capture it and add to your deck (need an item though).
The fairies get exp and level up getting new skill slots and improved stats.

There is quite a bit of hidden stuff
hoursPlayed: quests and even rare fairies to be found while exploring off the beaten path.\nSpecial fairies will unlock some abilities that will allow getting to previously unaccessible areas.\nFinding
voteText:
collecting and leveling up your fairy deck is quite fun and the fairy design is interesting and imaginative.

The music is good and the intro theme sung by Kariina Gretere fits the mood perfectly.
Zanzarah is one of the games i remember fondly and surprisingly didnt lose its charms over the years."

reviewText: ZanZarah: The Hidden Portal was the ultimate gem of a game that went mostly undiscovered due to poor media coverage back in the 1990's when all the attention was focused on the then A"-list titles.  Needless to say this excellent and divinely beautiful and inspired game passed under the radar and faded into obscurity.\n\nThis re-release enables the game to be played on modern systems and new operating systems.  The game play itself works well
recommended:
such as the main character "Amy" literally losing her head.  Also controlling a mouse cursor in any of the menus feels extremely laggy with the cursor taking a while to respond and jumping instead of moving smoothly.  Hopefully this will be addressed in a patch sometime soon.

Players duel fairies in various arenas and capture them in orbs (Pokemon Style) to grow their collection.  The game is a fantasy RPG adventure at the core.  There are many hours of fun to be had and many areas to explore.  There is a solid story which unfolds in bits and pieces as the player explores further and uncovers more of the puzzles and mysteries.

Despite the glitches in menu
hoursPlayed: this game is still every bit as entertaining and engrossing as it was when it released.  This is by far the very best game I have ever had the privilege to play.\n\n10 / 10"

reviewText:
This game feels very much like pokemon, as I'm sure others have probably already pointed out.  In fact, I'd go as far as to say it's impossible not to instantly compae them unless you have never played pokemon before.  The only thing that really sets this game apart is that it's in a 3d environment and set in a sort of folklorish fantasy land full of elves and fairies and goblins.  I happen to be a fan of that genre, so I thought that was pretty cool.

I won't get too much into the story, but the gameplay consists of running through scenic areas, looking for hidden items, bumping into other fairy trainers that want to fight you, and catching new kinds of fairies (in what are basically pokeballs) until you get to the next zone, which futhers the plot and gives you access to new kinds of fairies, which can have skills that also help you get past certain areas.  Again, very very reminiscent of pokemon, so if you love the good old days of red and blue, and want that in a 3d world with a whimsical fantasy feel, this game is definitely for you.  If you are more of a purist and hate ripoffs, stick with pokemon.  Keep in mind, this game was released only 4 or so years after pokemon.

Combat takes you to an arena that I suppose is somewhere in the fairy realm" or whatever
date: and takes place between two fairies at any given time.  Each fairy has certain stats that impact their ability to fly around and shoot other fairies
recommended: or resist attacks.  There are elemental types of damage so expect some rock/paper/scissors type party building.  A typical battle consists of you flying around the area
voteText: possibly switching fairies to the right element to match your opponent (which gets annoying
helpfulPercent: because the enemies will do the exact same thing as soon as you do) and then charging whatever ability you have and firing until it passes out and gets replaced by the next fairy in the opponent's roster.   This is my only main problem with the game.  I feel like they could have done a lot more with the way battles play out
votesHelpful: and the skill sets seem limited to mainly just "shoot this beam at that thing."  That having been said
votesTotal: it still feels really good when you take your newly evolved super fairy in against something and it's like flying around with a dragon instead of a butterfly.\n\nI'd recommend purely because the formula works.  It's fun and addictive and the world is vibrant and full of interesting creatures.  It's pokemon with faries
votesFunny: which either sounds amazing or awful depending on the type of person you are I guess."

reviewText:
It is back!
I loved it back in the days and I still love it!
So many wonderful memories and they all come back together with a lot of new smiles.
Sure, there might be some graphic issues and nowadays it feels very unsusual not to have a windows mode, but hey - it is a 13 year old game!
And even if I was sceptical if I would like it after such a time or if it might be similar to movies I have enjoyed years ago that now just embarass me I of course gave it a try.
And there is no single moment of regretting it, on the contrary.
It is even more like: Hey, wow, look, even 13 years ago they managed to create this wonderful mood.
And even if the graphics seem a little out of date, they do not look like they were that old.
As I said: simply love it!

reviewText:
even though it's the still buggy version, I am now grateful that I have 1 integrated video card on my laptop, besides Nvidia 130M. The game doesn't run on NVIDIA cards, there is no fix for that, but when switching to Intel default card it works without any problems at all.

The game brings up alot of nostalgia, I remember playing the demo from a CD my cousin gave me one day, like 12 years ago. After installing it i played it non stop untill i finished it (1 sleep break). The gameplay is something that modern games lack: creativity. I love the x spell does damage to x fairy archetype, even if it has alot of elements from Pokemon games, the fact that it combines them with FPS combat it's what really makes this game shine. Not to mention countless hours of exploring the map and unlock areas that you always wondered what they hinder.

This is my favorite game of all times. If you don't have a Nvidia card, or if you have an additional Intel graphics card, buy it, you won't regret it.

10/10 I will play it again somewhere in the near future.

reviewText:
EDIT: Repurchased on new PC and after messing around with the settings, someone in the discussion hub pointed out that changing your resolution to a x32 setting fixes the problems on some computers. The game is fantastic and plays great now. Love it. Still wouldn't reccomend a purchase unless you know for certain this fix will sort it.
Playing on a Radeon R 360

Disaster isn't the word.
Upon loading up the game you're greeted to an impossible to navigate menu due to the framerate hitting 1FPS (Not an exaggeration). If you manage to take the 5 minutes to click new game and start up the world doesn't even load in on certain computers, Meaning that the game is quite literally impossible to play. Any attempt to run the game in compatibility mode results in locking yourself into an infinite loop of crashes and restarts.
Devastating shame. The game itself is genuinely an underrated gem but this version is a complete waste of money. First ever refund request from Steam. Would however definitely repurchase in the event of a patch or fix surfacing.

reviewText:
The game looked like it would be fun and most of the players that posted positive reviews must have older hardward. I have a brand new MacMini running Windows 10 and the game is unplayable due to  it unable to render the 3D world. The player is rendered fine but the game world is nothing but messed up polygons with skewed textures.

I search Google and the forums for answers and tried every suggestion I could find including the Python script and nothing fixes the bad polygon world.

I don't recommend this game for users with newer hardware or on Windows 10. If you are running Windows 8 or below on older hardware you may be fine.
voteText: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I loved this game so much. I played it constantly when it first came out. However I can't recommend this to anyone who doesn't want to persist through it's new found glitches.
The game is great, great storyline, great game play, great soundtrack and great graphics for it's time.
But unfortunately this re-release runs so slowly through all the  dialog and menus that it makes the game painfully slow to play. The general gameplay like running around the worlds and the battle sequences seem to run fine, so if you think you can get past a snail pace dialog (and there's a lot of dialog) then perhaps you will like this game: but it's so sad your opinion might be tarnished by this flaw that was never even there in the first release, back on older computers.
If they ever fix the problem (which I doubt since the creators of the game are closed for business) then I'll definitely change this to a positive review, because I honestly don't think anyone should miss this game in it's working condition.
voteText: 7 of 17 people (41%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I think the idea of the game is wonderful. I had many video glitches and sluggish contronller movement and response. Seem like this one needs tweaking. I liked the game it was just to hard to control under Every setting and the graphic issues made this game hard to play for long. I think updates wiill address these issues. For now I had fun, but will wait as bit to see if it updates the next time I load it. Hopefully that will address my issues. I would Love to see a Vsync button I think that would help. for 7 bucks, its an ok purchase. I can't wait to see if it gets fixed!

reviewText:
Stumbled upon Zanzarah have you?

Well, let me paint you a picture: There's triple A games out there to which I return once in a while to replay them. However with Zanzarah I have replayed it at least once each year since 2004, that's how much I enjoyed it and still do enjoy it.

I recommend you play it. If you do then you should know that the F1 key brings the ingame manual, cool info you might want to know, but amongst it there's also the Table of Effectiveness which illustrates elmental weaknesses and strengths. This is a crucial piece of the game, however it is not accurate. Some squares are not filled, likely due to the game having had an update which didn't change the old table. http://prntscr.com/98u7aq <- here is the correct table, all you have to do is have a bitmap of it, rename it to hlp004t" and drop it into Resources/Bitmaps folder and it will display in game.

Enjoy!"
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I bought this game when it was originally released and it instantly captured me.
Where to begin?

In this lovely game you play Amy, a teenage girl who gets drawn into the world of Zanzarah. In this magical Land where dwarves, swamp goblins and elves inhabit the world, everything revolves around Fairies. These creatures exist in the astral plane , where they often battle each other.

FIrst you defend yourself against rogue fairies who lurk in trees, stones, lakes... Later on you are able to collect them. The omnipresent rock-scissors-paper principle grants interesting battles. Its a constant challenge to set up your 5 member fairy team against current obstacles, like getting through a psi-fairy ridden cave. Should you at any point be at a loss which fairy is effective against the one youre battling, simply press f1 and keep scrolling till you can see the effectivness chart.

As the story continues you begin to realize into what you have been drawn into. While it starts quite peaceful you soon uncover that Zanzarah is in peril and its up to you to save it. As you get more and more powerful (or better put your fairies) you will be able to get to Areas which were previously inaccessible. There are not many games around which give you this feeling of accomplishment / progress. Which is even more true to the rune system: You are able to fast travel to many locations, which means (too) long walks arent necessary.


While today it may seemed dated (but still very nice to look at), back in the day the graphics were simply breathtaking. Lush green forests, mountan landscapes, swamplands... you surely get around in zanzarah. And every Area is so detailed, you can feel the love to detail that ran into their design.
Zanzarah can be compared with a certain asian game where red and white balls with little creatures in them play a big part ;)

In short: Get the game, immerse into the magical world of zanzarah, have fun :D
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I grew up playing this game, so needless to say when I found it on steam, I was very happy.

However, when I loaded the game up on my computer, I noticed it ran like garbage. The mouse movement was very slow, even if I put all the settings on low. The cutscenes ran ok, so I figured it was no big deal. However, when I actually loaded into the game, I must have loaded under the map or the game glitched out on me, because I was surrounded by red, green, and yellow polygons. I couldn't move, and the camera was stuck in one place.

I do hope this can possibly get fixed, because I do have very fond memories of this game, and it kills me that I can't play it.
voteText: No ratings yet
